variants.Description in input context: Mutations of the mitochondrial PINK1 are important causes of recessive Parkinson disease (PD). Clinical mutations impact on the function of Complex I of the mitochondrial respiratory chain.

Material used.Description: Using fruit fly and mouse models, the study examines the function of Complex I of the mitochondrial respiratory chain, mitochondrial depolarization, and synaptic vesicle mobilization in Drosophila neurons.

Readout description.Result Description: Complex I activity was impaired, leading to mitochondrial depolarization and reduced synaptic vesicle mobilization in Drosophila neurons.

Biological replicates.Description: The study uses multiple biological replicates from Drosophila and mouse models.

Technical replicates.Description: Mitochondrial function assays were repeated in triplicate for each sample.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type PINK1 expression was used as a positive control in rescue experiments.

Basic negative control.Description: Cells with knocked-out PINK1 were used as a negative control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: ANOVA was used to compare Complex I activity across experimental groups.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: Complex I activity greater than 80% of wild-type levels.

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Complex I activity less than 50% of wild-type levels.

Experiment Method.Assay Method: Synaptic function analysis in Drosophila neurons

Material used.Description: The study assesses synaptic vesicle reserve pool mobilization during rapid stimulation in Drosophila neurons.

Readout description.Result Description: Synaptic vesicle mobilization was significantly reduced in PINK1 mutant Drosophila neurons.

Biological replicates.Description: Multiple Drosophila lines were tested for synaptic function.

Technical replicates.Description: Each synaptic assay was repeated in triplicate.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type Drosophila neurons were used as a positive control.

Basic negative control.Description: Neurons with knocked-out PINK1 were used as a negative control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: t-test was used to compare synaptic function between experimental groups.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: Synaptic vesicle mobilization greater than 70% of wild-type levels.

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Synaptic vesicle mobilization less than 50% of wild-type levels.

Material used.Description: The study tests the effect of adding ATP to the synapse to rescue deficits in PINK1 mutant neurons.

Readout description.Result Description: ATP addition restored synaptic vesicle mobilization in PINK1 mutant Drosophila neurons.

Biological replicates.Description: Multiple Drosophila lines were tested for ATP rescue efficacy.

Technical replicates.Description: Each ATP experiment was repeated in triplicate.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type Drosophila neurons were used as a positive control.

Basic negative control.Description: Neurons with knocked-out PINK1 were used as a negative control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: t-test was used to compare ATP rescue efficacy between experimental groups.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: Synaptic vesicle mobilization greater than 70% of wild-type levels.

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Synaptic vesicle mobilization less than 50% of wild-type levels.
